rows.text: The famous Scot started with just a brief spell in charge, resigning after just twelve months due to the war.
In his second spell in charge post war Gibby grew a reputation as a much loved figure at Shamrock Park.
The legendary international had a total of a three-year spell at Shamrock Park in the early sixties.
Conway's first spell was just a year long one before taking charge again in a two-year spell.
Mackenzie came back for his third spell in charge becoming one of the club's most loyal managers the highlight was coming so close to winning the club's first ever league title in 1976.
Neil was appointed as Mackenzies replacement with the highlight of his reign being a Gold Cup win and an Irish Cup final appearance.
Scot Hutton was at the helm for four years winning several honours in the process.
Flanagan took charge for a brief spell in the mid eighties.
Kingon had a brief unsuccessful time in charge at the helm being sacked after one year.

McFall was a some what surprise appointment having originally not being considered at all but was appointed in December 1986.McFall cleared out the squad and the club won their first ever league title in 1990. The following season the club retained the league title and beat rivals Glenavon to win the league and Cup double also winning two other titles in 1996 and 2002 and resigned in 2016. McFall is regarded as the club's greatest ever manager.
Ex Manchester United defender Pat McGibbon was appointed as the successor to Ronnie McFall and resigned in October 2016.
Club legend Arkins was appointed as Interim boss for 60 days in 2016 and was a firm fan favourite.
Portadown native Currie was appointed on 5 December 2016 as McGibbon's replacement.Currie was relieved of his duties in February 2018 with the Ports sitting 5th in the Championship.
Former Port's striker Tipton was appointed as manager in February 2018.
